On this page

Email Templates ​

Overview ​

Standard email templates ensure consistent, professional communication with rights holders. Customize as needed while maintaining key elements.

Permission Request Templates ​

Standard Author Request ​

Subject: Permission Request - [Book Title] - [Your Reference]

Dear [Author Name],

I am writing on behalf of Elsevier to request permission to reproduce
the following material in an upcoming publication:

MATERIAL REQUESTED:
[Figure/Table/Text description]
From: [Full citation including authors, title, journal, year, volume, pages]
DOI: [if available]

PROPOSED USE:
Publication: [Book/Journal Title]
Edition: [if applicable]
Editor(s)/Author(s): [Names]
Publisher: Elsevier
Expected Publication: [Date]
Format: Print and electronic
Territory: Worldwide
Language: English (with rights to translate)

CREDIT LINE:
We will include the following credit: "Reproduced from [Source]
with permission from [Rights Holder]."

If you are the rights holder, please reply to this email indicating
your approval. If rights have been transferred to another party,
please let us know whom we should contact.

Please respond by [Date - typically 2-3 weeks out].

Thank you for your consideration.

Best regards,
[Your Name]
[Title]
Elsevier Publishing Services
[Email]

Publisher Request ​

Subject: Permission Request - Elsevier Publication - [Reference Number]

Dear Permissions Team,

Elsevier requests permission to reproduce the following material:

MATERIAL:
[Detailed description - figure numbers, table numbers, page ranges]

SOURCE:
[Complete citation]
DOI/ISBN: [identifier]

INTENDED USE:
- Publication: [Title]
- Publisher: Elsevier
- Format: Print and electronic editions
- Territory: Worldwide, all languages
- Duration: Life of the edition
- Copies: [Estimated print run if known]

Please advise on:
1. Permission approval
2. Any fees associated
3. Required credit line format
4. Any restrictions on use

We can provide additional details or complete any required forms.

Thank you for your assistance.

Best regards,
[Your Name]
Permissions Specialist
Elsevier Publishing Services
[Email]
[Phone]

Bulk Request (Rule of 10) ​

Subject: Multiple Permission Requests - [Project Name] - [X Items]

Dear Permissions Department,

Elsevier is preparing [Book Title] and requests permission to reproduce
multiple items from your publications. Please find the complete list attached.

SUMMARY:
- Total items requested: [Number]
- Source publications: [List titles/journals]
- See attached spreadsheet for complete details

INTENDED USE:
- Publication: [Book Title], [Edition]
- Publisher: Elsevier
- Format: Print and electronic
- Territory: Worldwide
- Expected Publication: [Date]

We would appreciate:
1. Bulk pricing if available
2. Single license covering all items if possible
3. Your standard credit line format

Please let us know if you need additional information or prefer
to discuss by phone.

Best regards,
[Your Name]
[Title]
Elsevier Publishing Services

Follow-up Templates ​

First Follow-up (Day 7) ​

Subject: RE: Permission Request - [Original Subject]

Dear [Name],

I hope this message finds you well. I'm following up on my permission
request sent on [Date] regarding [Brief description of content].

I understand you may be busy, but would appreciate confirmation of
receipt and an estimated timeline for response if possible.

Please let me know if you need any additional information or if there's
a better contact for this request.

Thank you,
[Your Name]

Second Follow-up (Day 14) ​

Subject: RE: Permission Request - [Original Subject] - Follow-up

Dear [Name],

I'm writing again regarding my permission request from [Original Date]
for [Content description].

Our publication timeline requires a response by [Deadline Date]. If I
don't hear back by then, we may need to consider alternative content.

Is there anything I can provide to expedite this request? I'm happy to
discuss by phone if that would be helpful.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,
[Your Name]
[Phone number]

Final Follow-up (Day 21) ​

Subject: URGENT: Permission Request - Final Follow-up - [Reference]

Dear [Name],

This is my final follow-up regarding the permission request below.
Without a response by [Final Deadline], we will need to pursue
alternative content for our publication.

ORIGINAL REQUEST: [Brief summary]
SENT: [Original date]
PREVIOUS FOLLOW-UPS: [Dates]

If you are not the appropriate contact, please forward this request
or let me know whom I should contact.

Thank you,
[Your Name]
[Phone number]

Response Templates ​

Acknowledging Permission Grant ​

Subject: RE: Permission Request - Thank You

Dear [Name],

Thank you for granting permission to use [Content description] in
[Publication title].

I confirm the following terms:
- Permission granted for: [Scope]
- Credit line: [As specified]
- Fee: [Amount if applicable]

[If fee applies:]
Please send the invoice to:
[Billing contact/address]

We will ensure proper attribution as agreed.

Best regards,
[Your Name]

Responding to Denial ​

Subject: RE: Permission Request - Acknowledgment

Dear [Name],

Thank you for your response regarding [Content description]. I understand
you are unable to grant permission for this use.

[If appropriate:]
Would you be open to discussing alternative terms, such as:
- More limited usage scope
- Different format (print only/electronic only)
- Shorter license duration

[Or:]
Could you suggest similar content that might be available for licensing?

Thank you for your consideration.

Best regards,
[Your Name]

Requesting Fee Clarification ​

Subject: RE: Permission Request - Fee Clarification

Dear [Name],

Thank you for your response regarding [Content description]. Before
proceeding, I'd like to clarify the fee structure:

Fee quoted: [Amount]

Could you please confirm:
1. What usage scope this covers
2. Whether bulk discounts are available (we have [X] items from your publications)
3. If academic/educational rates apply
4. Payment terms and invoicing process

Thank you,
[Your Name]

Special Situation Templates ​

Requesting Author Contact from Publisher ​

Dear Permissions Team,

I am seeking permission for content from [Citation], but need to
contact the author directly as they appear to have retained copyright.

Could you please:
1. Confirm the author retained rights, or
2. Provide author contact information, or
3. Forward this request to the author on our behalf

Thank you for your assistance.

Best regards,
[Your Name]

Escalation to Manager Contact ​

Dear [Manager Name],

I'm reaching out regarding a permissions request that requires
senior attention.

BACKGROUND:
- Original request date: [Date]
- Content: [Description]
- Previous contacts: [Names/dates]
- Issue: [Non-response/fee dispute/terms concern]

Our publication deadline is [Date], and we would greatly appreciate
your assistance in resolving this matter.

Please let me know if you'd prefer to discuss by phone.

Thank you,
[Your Name]
[Title]

Template Usage Guidelines ​

Customization Rules ​

ElementCustomize?Notes
GreetingAlwaysUse actual name if known
Content descriptionAlwaysBe specific
DatesAlwaysUse actual dates
Standard termsRarelyKeep consistent
ClosingOptionalMatch formality level

Tone Guidelines ​

  • Professional but friendly
  • Clear and concise
  • Specific about needs
  • Grateful for assistance
  • Firm but polite in follow-ups

Project Communication Templates ​

New Project Assignment Email ​

To: Editorial Contact From: rpcapplication@elsevier.comSubject: New Project: < [Project Title] >

Dear [Editorial Contact Name]:

The Copyrights Team is happy to work with you on this project. We have
assigned the project to [Assigned Team Member], who will contact you
directly with more information.

Please introduce Permissions Helpdesk team (permissionshelpdesk@elsevier.com)
to the editors/authors of this title at the earliest to assist on the
permissions process.

With best regards,
The Copyrights Team

Introduction Email to Rightsholder ​

Subject: RE: Introduction Email: < [Book Title], ISBN: [ISBN] >

Hi [Rightsholder Name],

I am [Your Name], who has been assigned with the title "[Book Title],
[Edition], ISBN: [ISBN]". I am happy to work with you on the permissions
of this project.

I have downloaded the permission log from RPC and request you to please
provide the manuscripts & art files for this title.

Also, please provide the print run for this title as it is not mentioned in RPC.

I look forward to hearing from you. Many thanks in advance and have a wonderful day!

Thanks & Regards,
[Your Name]
[Title] - Copyrights Team
ELSEVIER | Operations
Tel: [Phone] | Email: [Email] | url: www.elsevier.com

Permission Request Email (External Rightsholder) ​

Subject: Elsevier Permission Request: [PHI_Reference]_[Figure Number] From: permissionseeking@elsevier.com

Dear [Rightsholder Name],

Greetings from Elsevier!

I am [Your Name] working as a copyrights specialist at Elsevier. We are
interested in using one of the figures copyrighted to you in our upcoming
publication and we request your permission to use it in our Book.

I have listed the details of the request below.

Book Title          [Book Title]/[Edition] edition
Author of the Book  [Author Name]
Format              Print & Electronic
Distribution        Worldwide
Chapter Title       [Chapter Title]
Chapter Author Name [Chapter Author Name]

We request your permission for Elsevier and its licensees, affiliates,
successors and assigns to use, reproduce or, if it is necessary, to redraw
or modify the material listed below in this and all subsequent editions of
this Elsevier work and all revisions, versions, derivative works, translations,
ancillaries, adaptations, supplementary materials, custom editions, and in
advertising and promotion thereof, in all languages, in all formats and media
now known or hereafter developed, throughout the world and in perpetuity.
We will give full credit to the original source.

Source reference:
[Source Reference]

[Figure Image if applicable]

Best regards,
[Your Name]

Credit Line Change Email ​

Subject: Credit Line Change : [Book Title] <[ISBN]>

Dear [Rightsholder Name],

I am writing to you regarding a credit line change for the permissions
project, [Book Title].

Please note the change to be made to the credit line for the below listed
permission item(s).

| Item ID | Caption Title | Changes to be made to the Credit Line |
|---------|---------------|---------------------------------------|
| [Item ID] | [Caption] | [New Credit Line Source] |

Please get back to me if you require any clarification.

Regards,
[Your Name]

Credit Line Examples ​

OriginalUpdated Credit Line
Figure 10.1From Tóth, G., Montanarella, L., Rusco, E., 2008. Threats to soil quality in Europe. Joint Research Centre...
Figure 10.2Adapted from Hassani, A., Azapagic, A., Shokri, N., 2021... used under CC BY 4.0
Figure 10.3Figure was drawn to synthesize information described in the paper

Weekly Status Report (WSR) Email ​

Subject: Weekly Status Report - [Book Title]: [Edition], [ISBN] From: permissionseeking@elsevier.com

Hi [Rightsholder Name],

Good day! Please find below the status report of the project,
[Book Title], [Edition].

| Field | Value |
|-------|-------|
| Total no of Permission items | [Count] |
| Permissions to be worked | [Count] |
| Permissions Processed | [Count] |
| Permissions Resolved | [Count] |
| Permissions Yet to be Resolved | [Count] |
| Permissions in DE Query | [Count] |
| Permissions Yet to Apply | [Count] |
| Publication date | [Date] |
| Last Batch received date | [Single Batch/Date] |
| Project Deadline date | [Date] |
| Invoice amount spent till date ($) | [Amount] |

DE Query details:

| Item ID | Rightsholder | Comments |
|---------|--------------|----------|
| [Item ID] | [Rightsholder] | [Comment] |

Best regards,
[Your Name]

Analysis Report Email ​

Subject: Analysis Report - [Book Title]: [ISBN] From: permissionseeking@elsevier.com

Hi [Editorial Contact Name],

Please find below the Analysis report of the title - [Book Title], [ISBN].

| Field | Value |
|-------|-------|
| Total no of Permission items | [Count] |
| Permissions to be cleared | [Count] |
| Elsevier permissions | [Count] |
| Third Party permissions Split | Publishers: [X], Companies: [X], Courtesy of: [X], First time Contacts: [X] |
| High Fee permission items | [Count] |
| High TAT copyright holders | [Count] |
| Restriction list | [Not Applicable/Available] |
| Chapter author information | [Not Available/Available] |
| Approximate project completion date | [Date] |

Additional Notes:
[Notes about specific items, high fees, or issues]

Best regards,
[Your Name]

Project Completion Email ​

Subject: Project Completion : [Book Title] <[ISBN]> Attachments:

  • [ISBN]_PermissionLog.xlsx
  • [ISBN]_Cost Sheet.xlsx
Hi [Rightsholder Name],

Hope this email finds you well.

Please find the attached final permission log and cost sheet for this
title: [Book Title] [ISBN]

Thank you for your support with this project.

You will receive an automated survey email. I request you to fill in the
survey and provide us with your valuable feedback which will help us
improve our service.

Do let us know if you encounter any trouble in receiving the survey email.
Have a nice day!

Regards,
[Your Name]

Permissions Update Email (to Authors) ​

Subject: < [Book Title] ; [ISBN] > : Permissions update From: permissionshelpdesk@elsevier.comAttachments: Sample permission log.xlsx, Permission log.xlsx, Permission Guidelines.docx

Dear Author,

I hope you are well. I am writing with regard to the permissions for
the book [Book Title].

As you are likely already aware, as the author you are responsible for
obtaining written permission to reuse any third-party images, figures,
tables and/or substantial text excerpts appearing in your [chapter/book]
and for providing copies of these permissions.

Kindly note that we cannot legally publish the book until we receive the
permission files for your chapter/book.

If you have accepted writing the book/chapters in EMSS platform, please
follow the below steps:

Step 1: Submit both the completed permission log and copies of all
permission licenses for any third-party images, figures, tables, boxes
used in your [chapter/book] to Permissions Helpdesk
(permissionshelpdesk@elsevier.com). Please ensure to update the yellow
highlighted columns in the permission log which are mandatory fields.

Step 2: Obtain any necessary permissions licenses or other approvals in
writing from the rightsholders of the materials – this is usually but not
always the publisher for any published works. Please also be aware that
some publishers may have a longer turnaround time and some permissions
may also be subject to fees.

Step 3: If your [chapter/book] exclusively contains only figures/tables
created by you or your co-author and therefore requires no permissions,
please confirm the same to Permissions Helpdesk.

Best regards,
Permissions Helpdesk Team

Permission Reminder Schedule ​

Reminder Email Cadence ​

StageTemplateTiming
Intro EmailIntroduction emailDay 0
First ReminderGentle follow-upDay 7
Second ReminderMore directDay 14
First ChaserUrgent toneDay 21
Second ChaserFinal warningDay 28
Third ChaserLast attemptDay 35

RPC Tracking Fields ​

FieldDescription
Intro Email Due DateInitial email schedule
Intro Email Sent DateConfirmation
MS Due DateManuscript deadline
First Reminder Due/Sent DateFirst follow-up
Second Reminder Due/Sent DateSecond follow-up
First Chaser Due/Sent DateFirst chaser
Second Chaser Due/Sent DateSecond chaser

Permission Grant Confirmation Statements ​

Common author confirmation statements:

TypeStatement Example
Original Creation"All tables and figures are my original creation"
Figure Replacement"The attached figure is original; therefore, no permission is required"
No Third-Party"My chapter exclusively contains only figures/tables created by me"
